name: Grid

unions.name: Grid
unions.comment:
A grid of values.

It has a fixed amount of columns and rows.

It will wrap the borders (apply ModBy), making every position valid.

    grid |> Dict.get ( -1, 0 ) == grid |> Grid.get ( columns - 1, 0 )

If instead you want to have hard border around your grid, use `Grid.Bordered` instead.

values.name: diff
values.comment: Keep a value when its position does not appear in the second grid.
values.type: Grid.Grid a -> Grid.Grid a -> Grid.Grid a

values.name: dimensions
values.comment: return the dimensions of the grid
values.type: Grid.Grid a -> { columns : Basics.Int, rows : Basics.Int }

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty grid
values.type: { rows : Basics.Int, columns : Basics.Int } -> Grid.Grid a

values.name: emptyPositions
values.comment: Get all empty positions in a grid, sorted from lowest to highest.

values.name: fill
values.comment: Create a grid
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> Maybe.Maybe a) -> { rows : Basics.Int, columns : Basics.Int } -> Grid.Grid a

values.name: filter
values.comment: Keep only the values that pass the given test.
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> a -> Basics.Bool) -> Grid.Grid a -> Grid.Grid a

values.name: find
values.comment: Find the first value that passes a given test.
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> a -> Basics.Bool) -> Grid.Grid a -> Maybe.Maybe ( Grid.Position.Position, a )

values.name: foldl
values.comment: Fold over **all** positions in a grid, row by row, from top down.
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> Maybe.Maybe v -> b -> b) -> b -> Grid.Grid v -> b

values.name: foldr
values.comment: Fold over **all** positions in a grid, row by row, from bottum up.
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> Maybe.Maybe v -> b -> b) -> b -> Grid.Grid v -> b

values.name: fromDict
values.comment: Convert an dictionary to a grid
values.type: { rows : Basics.Int, columns : Basics.Int } -> Dict.Dict Grid.Position.Position a -> Grid.Grid a

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Convert an association list into a grid.
values.type: { rows : Basics.Int, columns : Basics.Int } -> List.List ( Grid.Position.Position, a ) -> Grid.Grid a

values.name: get
values.comment: Get the value associated with a position. If the position is empty, return Nothing.

values.name: insert
values.comment: Insert a value at a position in a grid. Replaces value when there is a collision.
values.type: Grid.Position.Position -> a -> Grid.Grid a -> Grid.Grid a

values.name: intersect
values.comment:
Keep a value when its position appears in the second grid.
Preference is given to values in the first grid.
values.type: Grid.Grid a -> Grid.Grid a -> Grid.Grid a

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment: Determine if a grid is empty.

values.name: map
values.comment: Apply a function to **all** positions in a grid.
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> Maybe.Maybe a -> Maybe.Maybe b) -> Grid.Grid a -> Grid.Grid b

values.name: member
values.comment: Determine if a position is empty.

values.name: partition
values.comment:
Partition a grid according to some test.

The first grid contains all values which passed the test,
and the second contains the values that did not.
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> a -> Basics.Bool) -> Grid.Grid a -> ( Grid.Grid a, Grid.Grid a )

values.name: positions
values.comment: Get all non empty positions in a grid, sorted from lowest to highest.

values.name: remove
values.comment: Remove a vlaue from a grid. If the position is empty, no changes are made.

values.name: size
values.comment: Determine the number of values in the grid.

values.name: toDict
values.comment: Convert a grid into an associated dictionary

values.name: toList
values.comment: Convert a grid into an association list of position-value pairs, sorted by the position.

values.name: union
values.comment:
Combine two grids.
If there is a collision, preference is given to the first grid.
values.type: Grid.Grid a -> Grid.Grid a -> Grid.Grid a

values.name: update
values.comment: Update the value of a grid for a specific position with a given function.
values.type: Grid.Position.Position -> (Maybe.Maybe a -> Maybe.Maybe a) -> Grid.Grid a -> Grid.Grid a

values.name: values
values.comment: Get all of the values in a grid, in the order of their positions.

name: Grid.Bordered

unions.name: Grid
unions.comment:
A grid of values.

It has a fixed amount of columns and rows.

If case of a invalid position, it returns an error.

    grid |> Grid.insert ( -1, 0 ) virus == Err OutOfBounds

values.name: diff
values.comment: Keep a value when its position does not appear in the second grid.
values.type: Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a

values.name: dimensions
values.comment: return the dimensions of the grid
values.type: Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> { columns : Basics.Int, rows : Basics.Int }

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty grid
values.type: { rows : Basics.Int, columns : Basics.Int } -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a

values.name: fill
values.comment: Create a grid
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> Maybe.Maybe a) -> { rows : Basics.Int, columns : Basics.Int } -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a

values.name: filter
values.comment: Keep only the values that pass the given test.
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> a -> Basics.Bool) -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a

values.name: find
values.comment: Find the first value that passes a given test.
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> a -> Basics.Bool) -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Maybe.Maybe ( Grid.Position.Position, a )

values.name: foldl
values.comment: Fold over **all** positions in a grid, row by row, from top down.
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> Maybe.Maybe v -> b -> b) -> b -> Grid.Bordered.Grid v -> b

values.name: foldr
values.comment: Fold over **all** positions in a grid, row by row, from bottum up.
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> Maybe.Maybe v -> b -> b) -> b -> Grid.Bordered.Grid v -> b

values.name: fromDict
values.comment: Convert an dictionary to a grid
values.type: { rows : Basics.Int, columns : Basics.Int } -> Dict.Dict Grid.Position.Position a -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Convert an association list into a grid.
values.type: { rows : Basics.Int, columns : Basics.Int } -> List.List ( Grid.Position.Position, a ) -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a

values.name: get
values.comment: Get the value associated with a position. If the position is empty, return Nothing.
values.type: Grid.Position.Position -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Result.Result Grid.Bordered.OutOfBounds (Maybe.Maybe a)

values.name: ignoringError
values.comment:
Trys modifying a grid and if its fails it returns the original grid.

Please be aware, that by using this function you might introduce errors.
values.type: (Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Result.Result result (Grid.Bordered.Grid a)) -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a

values.name: insert
values.comment: Insert a value at a position in a grid. Replaces value when there is a collision.
values.type: Grid.Position.Position -> a -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Result.Result Grid.Bordered.OutOfBounds (Grid.Bordered.Grid a)

values.name: intersect
values.comment:
Keep a value when its position appears in the second grid.
Preference is given to values in the first grid.
values.type: Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment: Determine if a grid is empty.

values.name: keys
values.comment: Get all non empty positions in a grid, sorted from lowest to highest.

values.name: map
values.comment: Apply a function to **all** positions in a grid.
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> Maybe.Maybe a -> Maybe.Maybe b) -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Grid.Bordered.Grid b

values.name: member
values.comment: Determine if a position is empty.
values.type: Grid.Position.Position -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Result.Result Grid.Bordered.OutOfBounds Basics.Bool

values.name: partition
values.comment:
Partition a grid according to some test.

The first grid contains all values which passed the test,
and the second contains the values that did not.
values.type: (Grid.Position.Position -> a -> Basics.Bool) -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> ( Grid.Bordered.Grid a, Grid.Bordered.Grid a )

values.name: remove
values.comment: Remove a vlaue from a grid. If the position is empty, no changes are made.
values.type: Grid.Position.Position -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Result.Result Grid.Bordered.OutOfBounds (Grid.Bordered.Grid a)

values.name: size
values.comment: Determine the number of values in the grid.

values.name: toDict
values.comment: Convert a grid into an associated dictionary

values.name: toList
values.comment: Convert a grid into an association list of position-value pairs, sorted by the position.

values.name: union
values.comment:
Combine two grids.
If there is a collision, preference is given to the first grid.
values.type: Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a

values.name: update
values.comment: Update the value of a grid for a specific position with a given function.
values.type: Grid.Position.Position -> (Maybe.Maybe a -> Maybe.Maybe a) -> Grid.Bordered.Grid a -> Result.Result Grid.Bordered.OutOfBounds (Grid.Bordered.Grid a)

values.name: values
values.comment: Get all of the values in a grid, in the order of their keys.

unions.name: Direction
unions.comment: A abstract concept of a direction on a grid.

values.name: flip
values.comment: Rotates a `Direction` for 180 Degrees.

values.name: rotLeft
values.comment: Rotates a `Direction` clockwise

values.name: rotRight
values.comment: Rotates a `Direction` counter-clockwise

name: Grid.Position
comment:
This module contains two ways of representing a point on a grid:
`Position` and `Coord`. Positions are meant to be stored, and coordinates are
meant to to calculations with.


# Position

@docs Position, move, add, coordsTo

#Vector

@docs Coord, fromDirection, toDirection, distance, scaleBy, length

aliases.name: Coord
aliases.comment:
`Coord` is a non-comparable representation for 2D Coordinates.

Use this type for your calculations.

aliases.name: Position
aliases.comment:
A `Position` is a comparable representation for 2D Coordinates.

You should store your coordinates in this type.

values.name: add
values.comment:
Apply Coordinates to a position to get the relative position.

```
move amount direction == add ( fromDirection direction |> scaleby amount)
```

values.name: coordsTo
values.comment:
Returns the difference between two positions.

```
difference p1 p2 == p1 <------- p2
```

values.name: distance
values.comment:
Gets the distance between to points.
(The length of the difference)

```
distance == vectorTo >> length
```

values.name: fromDirection
values.comment: converts a `Direction` into a `Vector` with length `1`.

values.name: length
values.comment: Returns the length of the coordinate (distance to (0,0)

values.name: move
values.comment:
moves a Point some amount of steps in a direction. This is the most used
way how to change a position.

values.name: scaleBy
values.comment:
Scales Coordnates. Coordnates obtained by `fromDirection` have size 1.

```
fromDirection angle |> scaleBy l |> length == l
```

values.name: toDirection
values.comment:
converts **any** `Vector` into its nearest `Direction` value.

fromValue (0,0) == Right
fromValue (1,1) == Down
fromValue (-1,1) == Down
fromValue (1,-1) == Up
fromValue (-1,-1) == Up

name: Location

unions.name: Angle
unions.comment:
A Angle should store Elm angles (radians).

Use the functions `degrees`,`radias`,`turns` or `pi` to obtain a Angle.

```
Angle <| degree 90
```

aliases.name: Location
aliases.comment:
A `Location` a point, possibly stored in a dictionary. Thats why its a tuple.
But doing calulations with tuples can get very chaotic, thats why the module provides
`Vectors`.

aliases.name: Vector
aliases.comment: A Vector is used for calculations.

values.name: add
values.comment:
simple adds a vector to a location, from geometry we know that a vector is
actually just an angle and a length.

```
move length angle == add ( fromAngle angle |> scaleby length)
```

values.name: distance
values.comment:
The `Distance` between two locations is the length of the resulting vector

```
distance == vectorTo >> length
```

values.name: fromAngle
values.comment:
construct a unit vector from an angle

```
fromAngle >> length == 1
```

values.name: length
values.comment: Returns the length of the coordinate (distance to (0,0)

values.name: move
values.comment:
given a `Location`, a distance in some direction. This is the most used
way how to change a location.

values.name: rotate
values.comment: rotate a Vector

values.name: scaleBy
values.comment:
Scales a Vector. Vectors obtained by `fromAngle` have size 1.

```
fromAngle angle |> scaleBy l |> length == l
```

values.name: toAngle
values.comment:
An Angle can be constructed from a Vector.

```
{x=0,y=0} |> Location.toAngle == 0
```

values.name: vectorTo
values.comment:
The difference between to locations is a vector.

```
loc1 <----- loc2
```

the resulting vector points from the second value to the first.

name: PixelEngine

aliases.name: Area
aliases.comment:
A horizontal area of the content.
A `Area` defines how the content should be displayed.

**Note:**
An area can only contain elements of the same type.
So either you have tiles or images.

![A typical game](https://orasund.github.io/pixelengine/img4.png "A typical game")

aliases.name: PixelEngine
aliases.comment:
An alias for a PixelEngine program.

Your `main` function will have this type.

values.name: basicControls
values.comment: Subscribes to a keypress and sends the corresponding msg. This Function uses the default key layout.

values.name: colorBackground
values.comment:
A single color background.
It uses [avh4/elm-color](https://package.elm-lang.org/packages/avh4/elm-color/latest).

```
colorBackground (Color.rgb255 20 12 28)
```

values.name: customControls
values.comment:
Subscribes to a keypress using custom key layouts.

It uses [key values](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/KeyboardEvent/key) for the String.
You can use this [website](http://keycode.info) to find out the key value.
values.type: (String.String -> Maybe.Maybe PixelEngine.Input) -> (PixelEngine.Input -> Maybe.Maybe msg) -> Platform.Sub.Sub (Maybe.Maybe msg)

values.name: defaultInputs
values.comment:
The default layout:

  - A/ArrowLeft - `InputLeft`
  - W/ArrowUp - `InputUp`
  - D/ArrowRight - `InputRight`
  - S/ArrowDown - `InputDown`
  - Space/Enter - `InputA`
  - X/Backspace/Esc - `InputB`
  - Q - `InputX`
  - E - `InputY`

values.name: game
values.comment:
A prewired PixelEngine frame.

Use it just like `document` from [elm/browser](https://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm/browser/latest/Browser).
values.type: { init : flags -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg ), update : msg -> model -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg ), subscriptions : model -> Platform.Sub.Sub msg, view : model -> { title : String.String, options : Maybe.Maybe (PixelEngine.Options.Options msg), body : List.List (PixelEngine.Area msg) }, controls : PixelEngine.Input -> Maybe.Maybe msg, width : Basics.Float } -> Platform.Program flags (PixelEngine.Model model msg) (PixelEngine.Msg msg)

values.name: gameWithCustomControls
values.comment:
A game using custom controls.

The default controls should be enough to start,
but maybe you want to write a spelling game,
or its nessesary that very specifc keys are used?
values.type: { init : flags -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg ), update : msg -> model -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg ), subscriptions : model -> Platform.Sub.Sub msg, width : Basics.Float, view : model -> { title : String.String, options : Maybe.Maybe (PixelEngine.Options.Options msg), body : List.List (PixelEngine.Area msg) }, controls : ( String.String -> Maybe.Maybe PixelEngine.Input, PixelEngine.Input -> Maybe.Maybe msg ) } -> Platform.Program flags (PixelEngine.Model model msg) (PixelEngine.Msg msg)

values.name: gameWithNoControls
values.comment:
A game with no controls.

Use it just like `document` from [elm/browser](https://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm/browser/latest/Browser).
values.type: { init : flags -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg ), update : msg -> model -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg ), subscriptions : model -> Platform.Sub.Sub msg, width : Basics.Float, view : model -> { title : String.String, options : Maybe.Maybe (PixelEngine.Options.Options msg), body : List.List (PixelEngine.Area msg) } } -> Platform.Program flags (PixelEngine.Model model msg) (PixelEngine.Msg msg)

values.name: heightOf
values.comment:
Returns the height of a list of Areas

This can be used to return the height of a `tiledArea`.
For a `imageArea` this function is trivial.

values.name: imageArea
values.comment:
An area containing images that can be arranged freely.

This is a complete contrast to the way how `tiledArea` is working.
Usefull applications are GUIs, menus or loading screens.

Checkout [PixelEngine.Graphics.Image](PixelEngine-Graphics-Image) for more information.

This area has the following options:

  - `height` - The height or the `Area` in pixels.
  - `background` - The background of the `Area`.
values.type: { height : Basics.Float, background : PixelEngine.Background } -> List.List ( ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ), PixelEngine.Image.Image msg ) -> PixelEngine.Area msg

values.name: imageBackground
values.comment:
An image that gets repeated.

```
Image "groundTile.png"
```
values.type: { source : String.String, width : Basics.Float, height : Basics.Float } -> PixelEngine.Background

values.name: tiledArea
values.comment:
An area for using tilesets.

It supports one tileset at a time,
that means all sprites must be of the same size and stored as a grid in one single file.
This area is useful for displaying the playing field of a game.

Checkout [PixelEngine.Graphics.Tile](PixelEngine-Graphics-Image) for more information.

This area has the following options:

  - `rows` - The amount of rows of the grid. This value defines the height of the `Area`.
  - `tileset` - The tileset that will be used for all elements in the `Area`.
  - `background` - The background of the `Area`.
values.type: { rows : Basics.Int, tileset : PixelEngine.Tile.Tileset, background : PixelEngine.Background } -> List.List ( ( Basics.Int, Basics.Int ), PixelEngine.Tile.Tile msg ) -> PixelEngine.Area msg

values.name: toHtml
values.comment: Displays content of the game.
values.type: { width : Basics.Float, options : Maybe.Maybe (PixelEngine.Options.Options msg) } -> List.List (PixelEngine.Area msg) -> Html.Html msg

values.name: withMobileSupport
values.comment:
Adds mobile support to the options.
It needs the window size.

<PixelEngine> provides a fully wired program that takes care of everything.
values.type: { windowSize : { width : Basics.Float, height : Basics.Float }, controls : PixelEngine.Input -> Maybe.Maybe msg } -> PixelEngine.Options.Options msg -> PixelEngine.Options.Options msg

name: PixelEngine.Image

aliases.name: Image
aliases.comment:
A `Image` is actually a very general type: As we will see later,
even tiles are essentially images.
The following functions are intended to be modular.

values.name: clickable
values.comment:
Makes an `Image` clickable

Use this to create the `onClick` event from [Html.Events](https://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm/html/latest/Html-Events#onClick).

values.name: fromSrc
values.comment:
The basic image constructor.
The string contains the url to the image

    fromSrc "aStone.png"

values.name: fromText
values.comment:
Created an Image from a text-string and the Tileset of the font.

It only supports Ascii characters.

This package comes with a [collection of Fonts](https://github.com/Orasund/pixelengine/wiki/Collection-of-Fonts)
that are free to use.

values.name: fromTextWithSpacing
values.comment:
Created an Image from a text-string and the Tileset of the font.

It only supports Ascii characters.

The first argument is the spaceing between letters. Use negative values to place
the letters nearer to echother.

This package comes with a [collection of Fonts](https://github.com/Orasund/pixelengine/wiki/Collection-of-Fonts)
that are free to use.

values.name: fromTile
values.comment:
`Tiles` are essentially also images,
therefore this constructor transforms a `Tile` and a `Tileset` into an `Image`.

    fromTile (tile ( 0, 0 ))
        (tileset
            { source = "tiles.png"
            , width = 80
            , height = 80
            }
        )
        == image "tiles.png"

**Note:**
`fromTile` displays only the `width` and `height` of the image, that where given.
This means setting `width` and `height` to `0` would not display the image at all.

    fromTile (tile ( 0, 0 ) |> movable "uniqueId")
        == fromTile (tile ( 0, 0 ))
        |> movable "uniqueId"

**Note:**
If you want to animate an `Image` use this function instead.

values.name: jumping
values.comment:
Pauses a the transition of a `movable` image.

**Only use in combination with `movable`:**

    image "teleportingEnemy.png" |> movable "name" |> jumping

Use this function if a tile has the `movable`-property, but you would like to
remove it without causing any unwanted side effects.

values.name: monochrome
values.comment:
Adds a background color.

\*\* This makes the the Image non-transparent \*\*

This can be used to simulate monochrome sprites or to implement team colors.

values.name: movable
values.comment:
Creates a image transition between positions.
This is useful for images that will change their position during the game.

    image "enemy.png" |> movable "name"

**Note:**
The string should be unique, if not the transition might fail every now and then.

**Note:**
The string will be a id Attribute in a html node, so be careful not to use names that might be already taken.

values.name: multipleImages
values.comment:
It is possible to compose an `Image` from a set of other images.
The two `Floats` are realtive coordinates.

    ((100,100),image "img.png")
    =
    ((20,50), multipleimages [((80,50),image "img.png")])

Sub-images loose the ability to be movable:

    multipleimages [((x,y),image "img.png" |> movable "id")]
    =
    multipleimages [((x,y),image "img.png")]

Instead use the following:

    image "img.png" |> movable "id"
    =
    multipleimages [((0,0),image "img.png")] |> movable "id"
values.type: List.List ( ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ), PixelEngine.Image.Image msg ) -> PixelEngine.Image.Image msg

values.name: onClick
values.comment:
[DEPRECATED]

Use `clickable` instead.

values.name: withAttributes
values.comment:
Adds custom attributes.

Use the [Html.Attributes](https://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm/html/latest/Html-Attributes).
values.type: List.List (Html.Attribute msg) -> PixelEngine.Image.Image msg -> PixelEngine.Image.Image msg

name: PixelEngine.Options
comment:
Options tweak different aspects of your program.

#Transitions
Adding a transitions between screens.

The information for the transition will be written in the `Option` class from
[PixelEngine.Graphics](PixelEngine-Graphics).

To get started, copy the following example:

    options
        |> Transition.withTransitionFrom
            ListOfArea
            (Transition.customTransition
                "death_transition"
                [ ( 0, "opacity:1;filter:grayscale(0%) blur(0px);" )
                , ( 1, "opacity:1;filter:grayscale(70%) blur(0px);" )
                , ( 3, "opacity:0;filter:grayscale(70%) blur(5px);" )
            ])


## Main Function

@docs withTransitionFrom


## Area

@docs Transition, transition


## Options

@docs Options, default, withAnimationFPS, withMovementSpeed, withScale

values.name: default
values.comment: Defines the width of the game.

values.name: transition
values.comment:
The default constructor for a `Transition`.

For the future I have planed to make transitions modular, similar to a `Msg` or a `Sub`.

    Transition.transition
        "death_transition"
        [ ( 0, "opacity:1;filter:grayscale(0%) blur(0px);" )
        , ( 1, "opacity:1;filter:grayscale(70%) blur(0px);" )
        , ( 3, "opacity:0;filter:grayscale(70%) blur(5px);" )
        ]

The first value is the duration of the effect, the second is the CSS-command at that point in time.
So the example will compile to something like this:

    dealth_transition:
    0% {opacity:1;filter:grayscale(0%) blur(0px);}
    25% {opacity:1;filter:grayscale(70%) blur(0px);}
    100% {opacity:0;filter:grayscale(70%) blur(5px);}

**Note:**
A screen will be automatically hidden after a transition,
so the example would also work without the opacity-parameter.
values.type: String.String -> { start : String.String, keyFrames : List.List (Maybe.Maybe String.String), end : String.String } -> PixelEngine.Options.Transition

values.name: withAnimationFPS
values.comment:
Sets the Frames per Seconds for Animations.

Value must be positv or else the function will be ignored.

**Default value:** `1`

values.name: withMovementSpeed
values.comment:
The speed of movement in seconds.

**Default value:** `0.2`

values.name: withScale
values.comment:
Scales up everything.

Use only power of `2` as scale to ensure crisp pixels.

**Default value:** `1`

values.name: withTransitionFrom
values.comment:
adds the `Transition` to the `Options`.

The first argument is the List or Areas taken **before** the transition is applied.
(e.g. the last state)
values.type: List.List (PixelEngine.Graphics.Data.Area.Area msg) -> PixelEngine.Options.Transition -> PixelEngine.Options.Options msg -> PixelEngine.Options.Options msg

name: PixelEngine.Tile

aliases.name: Tile
aliases.comment:
A `Tile` defines a sprite in a `Tileset`.
The following functions are intended to be modular.

A example for a `tile` could be:

    tile ( 1, 2 ) |> animated 1 |> movable "uniqueName"

aliases.name: Tileset
aliases.comment: A Tileset contains the actuall image that a `Tile` can reference.

values.name: animated
values.comment:
Adds animations to a `Tile`.
The sprites of the animation must be arranged horizontally in the `Tileset`.

The first argument give the amount of steps of the animation (one less then the number of sprites.)

The following code specifies a `Tile` with 3+1 frames

    tile ( 0, 0 ) |> animated 3

**Note:**
Setting the steps to `0` describes a tile with no animation.

    tile ( 0, 0 ) |> animated 0 == tile ( 0, 0 )

![animation](https://orasund.github.io/pixelengine/docs/img2.png "animation")

**Note:**
Negaive steps are not supported, in this case no animation will be played.

values.name: clickable
values.comment:
Makes an `Tile` clickable

Use this to create the `onClick` event from [Html.Events](https://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm/html/latest/Html-Events#onClick).

values.name: fromPosition
values.comment:
The basic `Tile` constructor.

The first argument is the position of the sprite in the `tileset`.

As an example

    tile ( 3, 2 )

is the 3 row in the second column of the `Tileset`.

![a tileset](https://orasund.github.io/pixelengine/docs/img3.png "a tileset")

values.name: fromText
values.comment:
Created a List of Tiles from a String and a Offset.

It only supports ASCII characters.

The Offset `(Int,Int` should point to the sprite repesenting the space-character.

This package comes with a [collection of Fonts](https://github.com/Orasund/pixelengine/wiki/Collection-of-Fonts)
that are free to use.

values.name: jumping
values.comment:
Pauses the transition of a `movable` tile.

**Only use in combination with `movable`:**

    tile ( 0, 0 ) |> movable "name" |> jumping

Use this function if a `Tile` has the `movable`-property and you would like to
remove it temporarily without causing any unwanted side effects.

values.name: monochrome
values.comment:
Adds a background color.

\*\* This makes the the Tile non-transparent \*\*

This can be used to simulate monochrome sprites or to implement team colors.

values.name: movable
values.comment:
Makes a `Tile` transition between positions.
This is useful for sprites that will change their position during the game.

    tile ( 0, 0 ) |> movable "name"

**Note:**
Once a `Tile` has this property, it can **NOT** be removed during the game.

**Note:**
The string should be unique,. If not then the transition might fail every now and then.

**Note:**
The string will be a id Attribute in a html node, so be careful not to use names that might be already taken.

values.name: tileset
values.comment:
The `Tileset` constructor has the following parameters:

  - `source` - The adress to the file
  - `spriteWidth` - The size of a single sprite in the `Tileset` (in pixels)
  - `spriteHeight` - The height of a single sprite (also in pixels)

For the following defines the `Tileset` used in the examples of this module.

    { width: 16
    , height 16
    , source: "https://orasund.github.io/pixelengine/tileset.png"
    }
values.type: { source : String.String, spriteWidth : Basics.Int, spriteHeight : Basics.Int } -> PixelEngine.Tile.Tileset

values.name: withAttributes
values.comment:
Adds custom attributes.

use the [Html.Attributes](https://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm/html/latest/Html-Attributes).
values.type: List.List (Html.Attribute msg) -> PixelEngine.Tile.Tile msg -> PixelEngine.Tile.Tile msg
